content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

user_context_message_data.about_model_message:
don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.

TTS systems play a vital role in improving accessibility, particularly for individuals with learning disabilities and visual impairments, as they can have any text read aloud.

entries.title: Transcribe audio with Google Gemini for free - here's how to do it
entries.snippet: Google Gemini now offers a free tool for transcribing audio files up to 10 minutes long. Users can upload up to 10 audio files at once, provided their combined length doesn't exceed the time limit. Compatible formats include MP3, AAC, and WAV. To begin, users can access Gemini via its website or app, select the upload option, and choose their desired audio file. Once uploaded, a prompt like "transcribe this speech" initiates the process. If an error occurs, retrying usually resolves the issue. Transcriptions are generated quickly, though they may include filler words (e.g., "uhms" and "ahs"). Users can instruct Gemini to clean the transcript by prompting it to remove such filler words. Additionally, Gemini can help summarize the audio or extract key points, making it a versatile tool for various transcription needs.

entries.title: ElevenLabs' AI Reader app can now narrate text in 32 languages
entries.snippet: ElevenLabs has globally launched its AI Reader text-to-speech app, expanding support to 32 languages, including Spanish, French, Arabic, Mandarin, and Hindi. Initially released in June in the US, UK, and Canada, the app is now available worldwide on iOS and Android. It allows users to listen to various text formats such as PDFs, articles, newsletters, and ePub files, though it does not support Kindle or Apple Books. The app offers a wide range of AI-generated voices, including those of deceased celebrities like Judy Garland and James Dean, with licensed usage approved by their heirs. The Reader app is free to use and doesn’t consume credits from ElevenLabs' main subscription plan. A premium version is in development, but the company assures a generous free tier will remain.

entries.title: Mega-TTS: Zero-Shot Text-to-Speech at Scale with Intrinsic Inductive Bias
Best free text-to-speech software of 2025
entries.snippet: This document from TechRadar outlines the best free text-to-speech (TTS) software of 2025, highlighting tools that convert written text into spoken words. These tools are increasingly important for accessibility, content creation, productivity enhancement, and proofreading. The best overall pick is Natural Reader, praised for its user-friendly interface, support for various file formats, OCR, and custom playback options. Panopreter Basic is ideal for beginners, offering a simple interface and MP3/WAV exports. Zabaware Text-to-Speech Reader excels at reading web content but has limited voice options. Balabolka stands out for advanced users wanting custom voices, offering support for multiple file types and detailed voice customization. WordTalk, an add-on for Microsoft Word, enables TTS support in all Word versions with simple playback controls. The guide also answers common questions about format (MP3 vs. WAV), the SAPI interface, and what to expect from free software. The testing methodology considered usability, voice quality, and accessibility features, focusing on balancing functionality against the limitations of free services.

entries.title: You Can Now Use Stephen Hawking's Speech Software for Free
entries.snippet: Intel has released the assistive speech software used by Stephen Hawking—called ACAT (Assistive Context-Aware Toolkit)—as a free, open-source platform. Originally developed to enable communication for individuals with disabilities, ACAT lets users input text and control applications via facial muscle movements, using basic PC hardware with a webcam. While it's currently only compatible with Windows PCs and not designed for general consumer use, developers and researchers are encouraged to build on the toolkit, especially by integrating new input methods like proximity sensors, accelerometers, and Intel’s RealSense 3D camera. Intel’s goal in open-sourcing ACAT is to facilitate innovation in assistive technologies, providing developers with a strong foundation instead of building systems from scratch. Although still geared mainly toward developers, early user reports suggest ACAT is relatively easy to install and use. Intel is also working directly with patients and academic institutions to further test and develop the software.

entries.title: San Antonio Express-News partners with Everlit to offer free audio narration on articles
entries.snippet: The San Antonio Express-News has partnered with software company Everlit to provide free AI-generated audio narration for most articles on ExpressNews.com. This new feature enhances accessibility by allowing users to listen to articles, making it easier for people to stay informed while commuting or multitasking. The AI-generated voices were carefully selected by editors to reflect the character of San Antonio and are designed to sound natural rather than robotic. Audio versions can be accessed via a play button located just below the article's headline and lead image. Though the technology has been praised for its human-like quality, some mispronunciations may occur, which the staff will correct using Everlit's pronunciation library. However, this feature will not be available on the Express-News app or for certain special projects.

entries.title: Millions of Kindle users given big device update & it impacts the way you enjoy free books
entries.snippet:
Amazon has released a major update for 11th- and 12th-generation Kindle devices, introducing a new "Assistive Reader" feature designed primarily to help users with impaired vision. This functionality uses Text-to-Speech (TTS) technology to read books aloud, providing an alternative to traditional audiobooks. It integrates with the Kindle app across various platforms and supports real-time text highlighting during playback. Users must pair Bluetooth headphones with their Kindle devices, as they lack built-in headphone jacks.

Assistive Reader supports multiple languages, including English, Spanish, German, and French. However, not all ebooks are compatible; only those with the Enhanced Typesetting feature can use this tool. The feature was initially tested in July but temporarily withdrawn. Alongside the update, Amazon is promoting its Kindle Unlimited subscription service, which offers access to millions of books and is currently available with a 30-day free trial. The update is expected to enhance Kindle's appeal, especially among readers looking for more accessible reading options.
